Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2015 11:47AM angelia50 wrote: my forehead felt like I had it on concrete toward the end of it all and the noise of it. Seems they could make that thing quieter.

I dont' see why they can't reduce that sound, that bothered me more than the laying there did.

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2014 08:18AM angelia50 wrote: I haven't had the same experience but I have had the experience of finding out I have cancer. I would be glad the surgeon is double checking and even though you are worried, keep the thought of better safe than sorry. Better to be sure now that its nothing or if it is something, better to find that out now than 6 months from now.
Posts.Title: Waiting for your life to change? ExpatriateGirl ExpatriateGirl

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2015 09:18PM angelia50 wrote: you are doing much better than I was at this point. I was more afraid than sad. Have to say, I still feel afraid. I am also IDC grade 1 but I am not HER positive. You'll know more after your surgery. Keep strong, ask plenty of questions.
Posts.Title: Was told this evening I have IDC Cmo65 mel147

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2014 07:13PM angelia50 wrote: alexgram,you are so positive and looks like you have dealt with this a long time. I was diagnosed 6/14 and my pathology was good for it to have the IDC involved but I can't shake this feeling of doom. I am so happy to be alive but I have this constant fear there are cells still in there somewhere and the more I read, seems the more likely they are.  I think I was more positive until somebody asked the questions of in fact, wasn't it almost worse to have grade 1 since chemo won't help with it and its almost just dormant.  I had stage 1, grade 1, and didn't have chemo or radiation, which I am glad of but them, I worry something was missed but my doctor says my cancer responds more likely to hormone therapy instead of chemo. I don't know if this fear will ever go away and I worry that having that fear, will in the long run, cause my fears to come true.  I think stress makes it all worse.  For the most part, people around me think I'm doing fine and physically for now, I am but I guess its the fact that this can happen with no warning and you can have something growing that could be killing you and you aren't even sick.. Just scary.
Posts.Title: New here and just need to talk Siren40 AndreaR

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2014 06:38PM angelia50 wrote: JudyO, I feel the same as you and I wish they would change the wording on DCIS. I know several people who had that and then others will say oh, such and so had it and they are fine and I always have to tell them, no, they did not have invasive, its not the same thing, not the same thing at all. Just like most of the celebrities, they had DCIS but the public things oh, see, they are fine, like the Good Morning America Anchor
Posts.Title: Mad tonight at Susan Komen JudyO april485

Posts.Content: May 17, 2015 10:15AM angelia50 wrote: Stego, I have to admit, I had not followed through with having yearly mammograms as recommended. In May of 2014, I finally agreed to have a mammogram because I was having pain in my left breast. When I laid on my side, it almost felt as if I was laying on something. As it turned out, I had cancer in the right breast and had calcifications in the left but they required no surgery. So, weird thing is, the pain led me to the testing, but the cancer side was not having any pain. The MRI did find more things that needed attention in the right breast, but still nothing on the left. I kept saying are you sure nothing on the left, because its the one that had been bothering me but they said no, nothing there. I am grateful that I did have that pain, because had I not, no telling when I would have forced myself to seek attention. Just keep asking questions and hopefully, yours is just regular hormones but definately check it out.
Posts.Title: Pain in left breast for 7 months, no diagnosis StegoRawr78 StegoRawr78

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2014 01:35PM angelia50 wrote: jobur, I agree with what you said. I don't want to scare anybody, not at all but I was given some cream to put on prior to coming to the hospital that day and twice more when I arrived and it still hurt.  When I returned to the holding area, I told the surgeon that was terrible and she was surprised and asked if I had used the cream and said most people didn't have problems.  So, not sure what difference mine was.  When I woke up from the surgery, I was not in any pain and didn't have any pain for any of my fills or anything after and none for the 5 biopsies prior to my surgery, but that injection hurt and I don't think it had to do with pain threshold. Even the people that did it said they understood and knew it hurt.  Now, I will grant you, it only hurt for a few seconds, but I still say, that was more uncomfortable than the entire mastectomy was, but only for a few seconds, which seemed like minutes, at the time.
Posts.Title: Radioactive Injection into Nipple NOT TERRIBLE waynesgirl50 Motherofall6

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2014 10:36AM angelia50 wrote: Akitagirl, AMEN. I was really thinking that cream was going to save me, and I don't know what it would have been like had I not had the cream, but it hurt.  They said little bee sting and I said no, closer to big hornet sting. But, thankfully, only a few seconds, 3 times, and then, it was over, THANK GOD.
Posts.Title: Radioactive Injection into Nipple NOT TERRIBLE waynesgirl50 Motherofall6

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2014 10:54PM angelia50 wrote: I had the numbing cream but it still hurt. Only hurt a few seconds, but it did hurt. I cannot say if the cream helped, lord, if it did, I really feel for somebody having it without the cream.
Posts.Title: Radioactive Injection into Nipple NOT TERRIBLE waynesgirl50 Motherofall6

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2014 11:42PM angelia50 wrote: I did have the numbing cream, I was told to put it on before I left home that morning, which I did, and applied two more times when I got to the hospital. I can truthfully say, this procedure was the most pain of the entire mastectomy. I do agree it was short lived pain, only a few seconds, but for those seconds, it was bad and yes, the tech and person doing the injection said they knew it was painful and said they were sorry.  This was not for the wire guided, it was for the sentinel testing, so maybe some of these people are referring to injections given in the breast rather than the nipple area.
Posts.Title: Radioactive Injection into Nipple NOT TERRIBLE waynesgirl50 Motherofall6

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2014 12:20PM angelia50 wrote: slv 58, they probably would, since seems most of the ones doing the procedures are men.  I know when I expressed worry about having a lift done at time of my upcoming exchange, my plastic surgeon said it is fine, I've done hundereds of these and I said yeah, but you haven't had one done on yourself.  He said but ladies tell me and its fine.  I said you remind me of my husband when I was talking about how painful the compression mammogram was and he didn't seem to get it and I said well how about you imagine them putting your privates in a vise. Men, don't get me started.
Posts.Title: Radioactive Injection into Nipple NOT TERRIBLE waynesgirl50 Motherofall6

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2014 09:16PM angelia50 wrote: TheDivineMrsM, I agree with you about the misunderstanding that once its found, you are all in the clear.  I admit, I did not follow guidelines and did not have a mammogram for 20 years. At first, I wanted to beat myself up for this but then I began to think, if I had gone, yes, I would have found it earlier but I would have still had cancer.  I said that to a relative and she looked at me as if I was crazy. Again, I said me having a mammogram earlier would NOT have kept me from having this cancer. Yes, it would have been found earlier but it would have still been cancer. I was blessed that it was stage 1, even though since it was also grade 1, they estimate it likely had been there a while, but it was invasive, which is why I will never be able to feel safe, even though it was small, it was still invasive and nobody really knows if any of those cells escaped and I dont think the general public understands that.
Posts.Title: October.... The cosmic joke Swegirl Hopeful82014

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2014 03:34PM angelia50 wrote: I am new to all of this but I will tell you, i know the terrible fear you are having.  In May, I had a mammogram and received a call that I needed additional testing on both breast.  One had an obvious issue and one had calcifactons that needed a biopsy. My story is too long to write but what I can tell you is that I did have all the biopsies done and they are done with a needle and are not anything to fear, I mean, pain wise.  As it turned out, the side with calcficaitons was fine and nothing else was needed.  The other side, not so lucky.  If I were in your shoes, I would just have the biopsy and not delay it.  I never saw an oncologist until I was told I had cancer but that was not on the side with the problems like you are having, it was on the opposite side.  If your biopsy is clear, you won't need an oncologist, and I hope that is what happens in your case.  I had not had a mammogram for 20 years and I was blessed mine had not spread further than it did but you are early, you get that biopsy done and do it soon. You are probably fine but don't wait, get it done now.
Posts.Title: Help needed - just got a biopsy recommendation & feel lost Kat_76 Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2014 09:16PM angelia50 wrote: Nash54, you are so right. Just today, I was talking with my son and we were talking about a young man who had lukemia when he was about 6 years old and he's not in his late 20's and I said yes, that is a cancer that has a good cure rate, not like mine and he said but you don't have cancer, they got it all and I had to tell him again, they do not know that.  I did not have to have radiation or chemo and I don't think people really realize that nobody is sure its gone. I think they think I had surgery, its gone, done deal. It looms over my head like a dark cloud.

Why can't we ever be on the end of good odds, like winning the lottery or something?

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2015 05:50AM angelia50 wrote: wleeky, I am also from Kentucky and had a uni mastectomy but I did choose to have reconstruction.
Posts.Title: How is life with one boob? mtrebtoske316 Bekadawn1

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2015 09:39PM angelia50 wrote: I had to have mastectomy due to placement of what they had to remove. I did choose to do only that one side but have said, if I had to do it again, knowing what I now know, I think I would have done both sides. It has to be your choice and yes, you will be nervous when you have mammograms on the natural side. On the plus side though, you only have to deal with being uncomfortable on one side and know going in that you will have good use of your arm on the good side, although, I had no issues with my arm on the mastectomy side. I've recently had my exchange surgery and lift on the natural side, so this is the first time I've had some discomfort on both sides at the same time, and only having one side with issues is good too. Bottom line, you have to do what you feel is best for you. Good luck. I can tell you the surgery for the mastectomy is not nearly as bad as I feared it would be.
Posts.Title: Help Please! MrsTee Izzyfran

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2015 10:08PM angelia50 wrote: Mrs Tee, when I was first diagnosed, I debated about what surgery and actually, on my initial diagnosis, I had finally made up my mind for a lumpectomy. Then, I had a MRI and it found another issue, which was benign but was located directly under my nipple so the surgeon said taking that and the other two tumors I had would leave me disfigured. I said, compared to what????????? I mean really. So, mastectomy was what I had to face and I will tell you, I was devastated. I am 58 and heavy, so I was no pin up girl and sure didn't think I would be walking around naked but just the idea of it, just totally upset me. I sat and cried and cried and said I just don't want to do this. So I was sure in no frame of mind to do both sides. I had been praying from the beginning that God would show me what was the right surgery for me and when I decided on the lumpectomy and then, this ohter thing was found, I looked at it as he answered my question and made that choice for me, so mastectomy it was. As it turned out, they did find things in the surgery that the surgeon said would have likely made it impossible to get clear margins and it was a good thing I had the mastectomy. Plus, I did not have to deal with radiation. So, I had the uni mastectomy with tissue expander placed at time of surgey. I did not think I initially would want reconstruction but the further I got in, the less I wanted to deal forever with special bras and all of that, so I did opt for reconstruction. The mastectomy is kind of weird because it is pretty much numb after surgery so not a lot of pain. Drains are aggravating but not painful and like some have said, the incision for the lymph nodes was probably the most uncomfortable but not terribly painful.
Posts.Title: Help Please! MrsTee Izzyfran

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2015 10:11PM angelia50 wrote: Oh, and I see you have DCIS. That is the words I wanted to hear, but instead, I was told mine was invasive. So you are already a step ahead of those of us with invasive. You are going to do just great.
Posts.Title: Help Please! MrsTee Izzyfran

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2015 03:50PM angelia50 wrote: I had mast and expander at same time and yes, I had drains. I woke up with a bra on that had the little drain pumps attached with pins but my doctor had also given me a prescription for a cami prior to the surgery that held the drains. All I had to pay was a copay for those.
Posts.Title: no drains? littletatas hummingbirdlover

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2015 08:45AM angelia50 wrote: yes, I have those feelings. Immediately after my mastectomy, I would have anxious days when I would just feel overwhelming fear. I would just sit and cry and say, I'm scared. I know we all know others who have cancer and we all knew we could have it some day but now, we know we have it or had it, thats scary too, to know it could come back but I guess logically, its not different than thinking we could get it. Its been 6 months since my surgery and I don't dwell on it so much but its in my mind, the wondering if a cell escaped, the wondering if I'll get it in the other side, since I only had a uni, the wondering if I should have had chemo, wondering if the Arimidex is working, and like you, wondering if every pain is cancer. I think it just takes time to bury those feelings deeper inside but I'm sure, they will always be there.
Posts.Title: How do you stop the negative thoughts SpriteB Jek1983

The main difference I think was in the treatment, which is that it was not recommended for me to have chemo because grade 1 does not normally respond well to chemo, so I am just doing the ongoing Arimidex treatment and being watched closely.

There really is no right answer, its just whatever a person feels is right for them.

Once they removed the needle, it didnt' hurt. But, this may be different than what you are getting.

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2014 08:16AM angelia50 wrote: Holly, that is scary for all of us but I'm thankful it was still stage 1 when you found the new one. Posts.Title: Stage 1-recurrance percentage % risk? DXat32 Ygammyyet

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2014 09:31AM angelia50 wrote: probably 20 years ago, I had a biopsy and the doctor said I had the most dense breast he had ever seen. At that time, they did biopsies with incisions.  I had to admit, but I didn't have mammograms for many years and this June, I finally forced myself to go and I did mention that I had been told I had dense breast.  My mammogram did come back bad but I was told the same as you, I am 58 and they said well, not so much anymore, as you age, mostly fatty.  After my mammogram came back bad, I went to a breast cancer center for further treatment and they did in fact, deem me to have dense tissue and the pathology reports even have it on there.  Some of what I finally wound up having surgery because of was not found on even the latest equip they had at the breast center, but was found on their MRI.  So, you may be fine and you probably are, but I have found, if you really want the answer, go to a breast center that deals with this daily, not a family doctor. It also varies by state.  I live in Kentucky and there are no requirements but my breast center is in Tennessee and in that state, they are required to notify you that you have dense breast, which they did on my follow up letter.
Posts.Title: DENSE BREASTS oldgraymair54 agatha6

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2015 01:50PM angelia50 wrote: yes, I had that surgery in 2008. You have 4 parathyroid, I had one removed. They likely aren't taking all of yours. It was no problem, it was outpatient, no pain, you really can't even tell where the incision is. The plus was, literally within hours of the surgery, I felt totally different. I had gotten to the point I was so stiff, I could barely walk or get in or our of my car. That first weekend we went for a ride, I told my husband, hey look at me, I'm getting out of the car without holding on or grunting. It was like a miracle to me. I could feel myself getting stronger every day after that surgery.
Posts.Title: Parathyroid Surgery DEAK95 DEAK95

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2015 04:59PM angelia50 wrote: my doctor did parathyroid test after my calcium level was so high. He said that test is what would show if the glad was functioning correctly. I had an ultrasound at my local doctor's office and it did not find the bad gland but then I went to a specialist and they did find it on ultrasound. My incision was small and if I didn't point at it,I don't think you would see it. He did a very good job on that. I was amazed at how different I felt after that surgery. He estimated I had probably had the problem for 8 years before it got that bad and he said you don't get a high level like that over night. It can cause a lot of serious problems for your system, so don't wait to long to explore it.
Posts.Title: Parathyroid Surgery DEAK95 DEAK95

Posts.Content: angelia50 wrote: They did have a lady on the show today that had breast cancer many years ago and had later moved to her liver. She talked about how many years she had battled cancer, so hopefully, people will see that its more than just having an initial surgery and then, you are all better and the guest doctor they had, was very plain to point out, there is no cure for metastatic breast cancer. Dx 6/4/2014, IDC, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 7/13/2014 Mastectomy: Right Hormonal Therapy 8/17/2014 Arimidex (anastrozole) Surgery 12/18/2015 Reconstruction (right) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: The Doctors Show angelia50 angelia50

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2014 06:59PM angelia50 wrote: Naturalheal. I have to admit, I had not had a mammogram in 20 years, I am 58.  I really wanted to beat myself up over this in the beginning but then I began to think, you know what, I would have still had cancer even if I had a mammogram for the last 10 years or whatever.  I mean, my having the mammogram would not have prevented this cancer. Yes, maybe it would have been found earlier or maybe it would not, who knows.  I talked with a lady at a recent appointment while waiting for testing and she had first been diagnosed 12 years ago and she said she had mammograms faithfully every year and still, when hers was found, 1 year after a clean bill of health, it was already stage 3, so it came up that fast.  I am not sure why God choose to have me deal with this but I know he did and it was found when it was meant to be found. So, now all we can do is deal the best we can. Thoughts are with you.
Posts.Title: What was time between diagnosis and treatment? resigned LauraW68

I am not sure why, dont know if they have better equipment or what but it was a big difference.
